Theorem 1: If $f:\mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is a continuous function such that $f''(x) > 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, then $f$ is strictly convex.

Proof: Suppose $f:\mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is a continuous function and $f''(x) > 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. If $x < y < z$, then by the Mean Value Theorem, there exist points $c_1$ in $(x,y)$ and $c_2$ in $(y,z)$ such that $f'(c_1)=(f(y)-f(x))/(y-x)$ and $f'(c_2)=(f(z)-f(y))/(z-y)$. Since $f''(x) > 0$, then $f'(x)$ is strictly increasing, so $f'(c_1) < f'(c_2)$. Hence, $(f(y)-f(x))/(y-x) < (f(z)-f(y))/(z-y)$, which implies $f(y) < ((z-y)f(x)+(y-x)f(z))/(z-x)$. So, $f$ is strictly convex.

Theorem 2: A continuous and strictly convex function $f:\mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is not guaranteed to be unbounded.
